children.value: JSkyCalc: A convinient, portable observing aid.

2. Create a New Directory in Home Folder

I suggest creating a new folder in your home directory and placing the jar file in there. If your jar file is in your Downloads folder after downloading from John's site, you can copy paste the three commands to your terminal and you should end up in your
Run the java command on the jar file and it should start right up. If you don't have java installed in your system you will get a messege. Click on "more info" and it will take you to the
website.  Click on "Oracle JDK Download" button from
To add Mount Laguna Observatory to JSkyCalc, start by unpacking the jar file.
5. Add a New Site Location as Default
and add Mount Laguna Observatory as the first site (above Kitt Peak)--it will become the default.
Reconstruct the jar file and all the changes will take effect.
file and you will be able to start JSkyCalc from any directory.

# use jsky command in any directory to start JSkyCalc
alias jsky='java JSkyCalc'
CLASSPATH=$CLASSPATH:~/JSkyCalc
export CLASSPATH
to source the file and then use jsky command to start using JSkyCalc from any directory!
The following line is the general format for JSkyCalc (.dat) files:
Name_no_blanks hh mm ss dd mm ss equinox +++
It's fine if all your stars have equinox=2000. Here is an example of

The JDK is a development environment for building applications and components using the Java programming language. The JDK includes tools useful for developing, testing, and monitoring programs written in the Java programming language and running on the Java platform.

: JSkycalc expedites the "time-and-the-sky" calculations needed by observational astronomers. To follow the original directions on setting up JSkyCalc on your computer, go to John Thorstensen's website. His directions might be a little outdated (from year 2008) but they still work.
